Module MathUtils
Package mathUtils.calculus.complex

Class Complex

java.lang.Object
java.lang.Number
mathUtils.calculus.complex.Complex
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
public class Complex
extends java.lang.Number
This class represents complex numbers from mathematics. A complex number is a complexion formed by a real and an imaginary part. Because of this, they don't yield any concrete value, even though this class extends java.lang.Number. Note that calculations with instances from this class should be performed with the ComplexMath class.
See Also:
Imaginary, ComplexMath, Serialized Form

  • Constructor Details

    • Complex

      public Complex()
      The default constructor. This number becomes mathematically equivalent to 0.

    • Complex

      imaginary - The imaginary part

    • Complex

      public Complex​(java.lang.Number n)
      Constructs a complex number based on the given number. If the number is either entirely real or entirely imaginary, then the other part is set to 0. If the number is complex, then this number inherits the given number's values.
      Parameters:
      n - The number

  • Method Details

    • isNaN

      public static boolean isNaN​(java.lang.Number n)
      Returns whether the given number is valid. In other terms, evaluates if either the real or the imaginary part of this number is equal to Double.NaN.
      Parameters:
      n - The number to evaluate
      Returns:
      Whether this number is valid

    • isInfinite

      public static boolean isInfinite​(java.lang.Number n)
      Returns whether the given number is infinite. In other terms, evaluates if either the real or the imaginary part of this number is equal to Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY.
      Parameters:
      n - The number to evaluate
      Returns:
      Whether this number is infinite

    • isFinite

      public static boolean isFinite​(java.lang.Number n)
      Returns whether the given number is finite. In other terms, evaluates if neither the real nor the imaginary part of this number is equal to Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY.
      Returns:
      Whether this number is infinite

    • valueOf

      public static java.lang.Number valueOf​(java.lang.String str)
      Evaluates the given String. Any number of addition and subtraction can be performed. For example, Complex.valueOf("5 + 2i - 3 + 7i") yields the number 2 + 9i.
      Parameters:
      str - The string to parse
      Returns:
      The number in the given string

      Sets both real and imaginary part of this complex number based on the given values.
      Parameters:
      real - The real part
      imaginary - The imaginary part

      Sets both real and imaginary part of this complex number based on the given values.
      Parameters:
      real - The real part
      imaginary - The imaginary part

    • reduced

      public java.lang.Number reduced()
      Returns:
      The number that represents this complex number, where redundant components (zero-valued ones) are eliminated, thus yielding either a real, imaginary or complex number.

    • inverse

      public Complex inverse()
      Calculates the inverse (the reciprocal) of this complex number. Note that, even though values are changed, this object is still returned as a result to allow functional and stream-like calculations.
      Returns:
      This object with updated values

    • conjugate

      public Complex conjugate()
      Calculates the conjugate of this complex number. The conjugate of a complex number \( a + bi \) is said to be \( a - bi \). Even though values are changed, this object is still returned to allow functional and stream-like calculations.
      Returns:
      This object with updated values

    • scale

      public Complex scale​(double scalar)
      Scales this complex number from the origin by the given scalar. Even though values are changed, this object is still returned to allow functional and stream-like calculations.
      Parameters:
      scalar - The value by which to scale
      Returns:
      This object with updated values

    • getPolarForm

      public double[] getPolarForm()
      Calculates the polar form of this complex number. It is expressed as \( z = r \cdot e^{i\alpha} \), where \( r = |z| \) and \( \alpha = \tan^{-1} \frac{\Im (z)}{ \Re (z)} \). It is returned as an array of doubles, as in: \( [r, \alpha] \).
      Returns:
      An array with the polar form of this number

    • isNaN

      public boolean isNaN()
      Returns whether this complex number is valid. In other terms, evaluates if either the real or the imaginary part of this number is equal to Double.NaN.
      Returns:
      Whether this number is valid

    • isInfinite

      public boolean isInfinite()
      Returns whether this complex number is infinite. In other terms, evaluates if either the real or the imaginary part of this number is equal to Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY.
      Returns:
      Whether this number is infinite

    • isFinite

      public boolean isFinite()
      Returns whether this complex number is finite. In other terms, evaluates if neither the real nor the imaginary part of this number is equal to Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY.
      Returns:
      Whether this number is infinite

      Returns:
      Whether the given object holds the same mathematical value as this one or not.

    • toString

      public java.lang.String toString()
      Converts this complex number to a String. The result is the sum of the real and the imaginary part. For example, '5 + 2i' would look like this:
      5+2i
      Overrides:
      toString in class java.lang.Object
      Returns:
      The String equivalent for this number
